isis.stitle: Recall 00304 - Rear Emergency Window with Vandal Lock

recall.subject: Rear Emergency Window with Vandal Lock

defect.para: On some AmTran RE™ school buses, the rear emergency exit windows with Vandal Lock fail to conform to Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard (FMVSS) No. 217. These rear emergency exit windows supplied with a Vandal Lock system allow the locking mechanism to be partially released. In the partial release position, the lock does not provide electrical contact, and the engine may then be started while the rear emergency exit window is still improperly locked. If the window remains locked during an emergency situation, it could prevent evacuation of the passengers causing personal injury or death.

figure.caption: Lever Moved from Electrical Contact and Window Remaining in the Lock Position

defect.para: The vehicles involved are the AmTran RE™ buses built from July 31, 2000 through November 1, 2000.

ownernote.para: The customer notification letter required no inspection.

Repair kits were included with the recall notification letter to the customer. The notification letter gave the customer the choice to make the repairs themselves or contact their dealer to make the repairs.
The customer was told that American Transportation estimates that its dealers will have instructions to remedy this defect by December 12, 2000.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: This repair procedure involves removing the current screw and washer electrical contact and replacing it with a steel bar. Complete instructions on the repair procedure are included with the repair kit.

figure.caption: Rear Window with Bar Replacing Screw and Washer

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. NEW STEEL BAR ELECTRICAL CONTACT REPLACING SCREW AND WASHER

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified IMMEDIATELY from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
